greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: The Riordan square of the Bell numbers. Triangle T(n, k), 0 <= k <= n, read by rows.
comment: The Riordan square is defined in A321620.
Previous name was: Triangle T(n,k), 0<=k<=n, read by rows given by [1, 1, 1, 2, 1, 3, 1, 4, 1, ...] DELTA [1, 0, 0, 0, ...] where DELTA is the operator defined in A084938.
In general, the triangle [r_0, r_1, r_2, ...] DELTA [s_0, s_1, s_2, ...] has generating function
A130167*A007318 as infinite lower triangular matrices. - _Philippe Deléham_, Jan 11 2009
link: Paul Barry, Continued fractions and transformations of integer sequences, JIS 12 (2009) 09.7.6.
maple: # The function RiordanSquare is defined in A321620.
mathematica: RiordanSquare[gf_, len_] := Module[{T}, T[n_, k_] := T[n, k] = If[k == 0, SeriesCoefficient[gf, {x, 0, n}], Sum[T[j, k - 1] T[n - j, 0], {j, k - 1, n - 1}]]; Table[T[n, k], {n, 0, len - 1}, {k, 0, n}]];
RiordanSquare[Sum[x^k/Product[1 - j x, {j, 1, k}], {k, 0, 10}], 10] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Jun 15 2019, from Maple *)
xref: First column are the Bell numbers A000110.
Row sums are A154381, alternating row sums are A000007.
results.author: _Paul Barry_, Jan 08 2009
